parameters.source_text:
Case 12-4
The Jesus Christian Transplant:
Brainwashed into Donating a Kidney?
Ash Falkingham, a 22-year-old man from Sydney, Australia, wanted to
donate one of his kidneys to a stranger in Toronto, Canada, as an act of
kindness. Through the Internet he met Sandi Sabloff, who needed a kidney
transplant. One of her kidneys had failed completely and the second was
failing as well. Legal complications prevented him from making the gift in
Australia so he traveled to Toronto, Canada.
Prior to coming to Canada, he had been interviewed by telephone by a
committee. It included a psychiatrist, a social worker, and a bioethicist. On
March 19, 2007, he arrived at Toronto General Hospital where the organ
procurement was planned. He had further evaluation including meetings
with the committee and medical compatibility testing. Following the
screening, the hospital sent a letter to Ms. Sabloff indicating the transplant
would occur on April 30.
Some days later, the hospital began reassessing its decision.
Mr. Falkingham’s mother and stepfather, Kate and Nick Croft, had urged
the hospital to review the case further. They claimed he had been unduly
pressured into donating by the religious group, the Jesus Christians. It is a
group that believes it should act on its Christian faith by donating a kidney
to a stranger as an act of kindness. About half of the thirty members of the
group have donated, including its leader David McKay who had donated
one of his kidneys at the Mayo Clinic in 2003.
Mr. Falkingham’s stepfather was quoted by the National Post newspa-
per as saying, “I’m certain that the pressure to donate a kidney is one of the
many pressures involved in being a member of this group. ... I would say it’s
a cult. I would say it's a sect. I would say it’s a madness.” They claimed that
the group coerced members into giving kidneys as a way of gaining public-
ity. Meanwhile, the group claims it is their way of expressing spiritual devo-
tion and Christian charity. Mr. Falkingham said he was sent to a forensic
psychiatrist with a specialty related to brainwashing and undue influence.
After some five weeks of waiting, the hospital announced that it was can-
celing the operation. Robert Bell, the CEO of University Health Network, the
parent of Toronto General, was quoted by the Toronto-based Globe and Mail
newspaper as saying, “We need to make sure the [donor] has informed con-
sent for what this is all about, without any evidence of coercion and without
any evidence of value consideration being given to the donation of the tissue.”

data.vignette: A 22-year-old man has traveled from abroad to donate a kidney to a stranger he met online. He is healthy and has passed medical compatibility testing. The nephrectomy is scheduled in four days, and the transplant team has already completed preoperative planning. He states calmly that donating is a central part of his religious community’s practice and that he wants to proceed. His mother and stepfather contact the hospital and report that his group exerts intense pressure on members to donate and threatens social isolation for those who refuse. In interview, he appears competent and understands the surgical risks and long-term implications, but he avoids discussing whether he felt pressured. Hospital policy and local law allow proceeding with a living donation or declining it if consent is not clearly voluntary. You must decide now whether to move forward.
data.choice_1: Proceed with the living-donor nephrectomy as scheduled.
data.choice_2: Cancel the donation and close him as a living donor.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify key transplant-process plausibility details: specify whether this is a non-directed altruistic donation through an established program (e.g., paired exchange/NDD pathway) and that the donor has undergone the standard independent living-donor advocate (ILDA) evaluation and psychosocial assessment. Add that the current concern arose after that evaluation or that the ILDA is re-engaged urgently. Also specify whether the recipient is identified/approved by the program (so 'stranger met online' does not imply a potentially prohibited directed solicitation arrangement) and that the hospital has a protocol for assessing coercion/undue influence in living donation.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add a jurisdiction-anchoring sentence making both options clearly legally defensible, e.g.: 'Under applicable transplant regulations and state law, the team may decline any living donor if voluntariness is in doubt, and may proceed if the donor is an adult with capacity who provides voluntary informed consent after independent evaluation.' Also clarify that canceling can be done without disclosing reasons to the recipient to protect the donor (common practice), to avoid implying wrongful breach.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, canceling seems clearly favored because consent is 'not clearly voluntary' and there is a report of threats; this makes proceeding look ethically/clinically risky and potentially noncompliant. To restore genuine equipoise, add countervailing facts that make proceeding defensible: e.g., the donor consistently affirms desire to donate across multiple private interviews, denies coercion when asked directly, has independent financial means (no payment), has lived outside the community for years, and the ILDA/psychiatry evaluation finds no evidence of coercion though acknowledges possible subtle influence. Alternatively, soften the mother's report (e.g., 'concern' rather than 'threatens') and include possibility of family bias/conflict, while keeping uncertainty about undue influence.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the dilemma so neither option is ethically/clinically dominant. Right now, credible third-party reports of coercion make cancellation feel like the only defensible choice under standard living-donor ethics (voluntariness is foundational). To restore equipoise, add ambiguity and countervailing moral costs on BOTH sides: (1) Strengthen evidence supporting voluntariness (e.g., multiple independent interviews over time with an independent donor advocate; donor consistently articulates personal reasons and states he can refuse without retaliation; mother/stepfather have a history of conflict with his community). (2) Clarify what ‘cancel and close him’ entails (e.g., permanent exclusion from living donation vs postponement for further assessment) and ensure it carries serious ethical costs—paternalism, potential cultural/religious discrimination, undermining a competent adult’s deeply held values, psychological harm from being prevented from a central life project, and practical harm given he traveled internationally and cannot easily return for re-evaluation. (3) Make proceeding ethically costly in a specific way beyond generic “risk”: e.g., credible possibility of undue influence/trafficking-like dynamics, institutional integrity concerns, and irreversible harm to the donor if consent is later judged compromised. (4) Consider reframing Choice 2 as ‘postpone/cancel for extended voluntariness assessment’ rather than irrevocably ‘close him’ if you want a closer call; if you keep permanent closure, explicitly justify why postponement is not feasible (e.g., he will lose the only available surgical slot and must decide before returning home, and the team cannot complete additional independent evaluation in time).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Soften potentially leading phrasing that nudges toward cancellation. For example, change “exerts intense pressure” to “reports significant pressure” and “threatens social isolation” to “reports potential social consequences within the community if he declines.” Add one neutral counterbalancing sentence documenting the patient’s own narrative of voluntariness (e.g., prior independent interest in donation, ability to refuse without immediate housing/financial dependence), while keeping uncertainty about coercion.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make each option ~10–15 words and avoid transplant-program jargon. For example: (1) “Proceed with donor nephrectomy as scheduled after confirming informed consent today.” (2) “Decline him as a living donor at this center and cancel surgery.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance framing so neither option is implicitly favored. Currently, the case strongly cues coercion (family report of threats, patient avoids pressure discussion, “consent not clearly voluntary”), making cancellation feel safer/standard. To restore equipoise: (1) add credible evidence supporting voluntariness (e.g., independent donor advocate notes long-standing desire to donate predating group involvement; patient provides consistent narrative across multiple private interviews; group has documented non-coercive practices), AND (2) add ethically weighty downsides to cancellation (e.g., recipient has limited alternatives/time-sensitive medical need without naming another specific patient as competitor; donor will face severe spiritual/community consequences he endorses; donor may feel profound moral injury if blocked). Also add ethically weighty downsides to proceeding (e.g., nontrivial concern about undue influence, risk of exploitation, institutional integrity). Ensure both sides have comparable detail and moral cost.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: The binary is not exhaustive because realistic middle paths exist: delay surgery for extended independent assessment, involve an independent living-donor advocate/ethics consult, require a cooling-off period, speak with the donor without family/community influence, or transfer evaluation to another center. To force a true binary, explicitly rule out deferral: e.g., donor’s visa/return flight and operating room slot cannot be moved; recipient surgery logistics will collapse if postponed; policy requires accept vs. close decision by a set deadline; donor refuses any delay and will leave. Alternatively, redefine Choice 2 as “postpone/cancel now pending further voluntariness assessment,” but then make it truly binary by stating postponement effectively ends the donation because donor will depart and cannot return.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Living donation under suspected coercion is heavily governed by professional standards (independent donor advocate evaluation, requirement for voluntariness, psychosocial assessment; coercion is generally a contraindication). As written, ‘declining if consent is not clearly voluntary’ makes cancellation the guideline-consistent answer. To make it gray-zone: clarify that required independent psychosocial/advocate evaluation has been completed and documented voluntariness, but conflicting collateral information emerged late and is ambiguous; or specify that legal/policy language sets a discretion threshold (e.g., ‘reasonable assurance’ vs ‘clear’) and the team disagrees whether that threshold is met. Add why guidelines don’t resolve the discrepancy (collateral sources unreliable/biased; cultural/religious communal obligations may be meaningful without being coercive; donor’s reluctance to discuss pressure may reflect privacy rather than undue influence).

data.vignette: A 22-year-old man traveled from abroad to serve as a non-directed living kidney donor through your hospital’s established transplant program. He is healthy, compatible within the program’s matching pathway, and has completed the standard medical workup, psychosocial evaluation, and independent donor advocate interviews. Across several private interviews he consistently states he has wanted to donate since adolescence and denies being offered money. The nephrectomy is scheduled in four days, and his visa and return flight make rescheduling impractical. His mother and stepfather call to warn that his religious community expects members to donate and that refusal can bring social consequences; they also have longstanding conflict with the group. When you ask directly about pressure, he says he would rather not discuss his community but reiterates that he can refuse and still wants to proceed. Late collateral concerns raise a real possibility of undue influence, yet blocking the surgery would end this donation and may cause him profound distress and stigma he accepts as spiritually meaningful. Hospital counsel confirms that either proceeding or declining is legally permissible under transplant regulations and hospital policy. You must decide today.
data.choice_1: Proceed with donor nephrectomy as scheduled.
data.choice_2: Decline him as a living donor at this center and cancel surgery.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that he would choose to postpone/cancel donation if it would shield him from community repercussions, but feels unable to say so openly (or explicitly asks you to stop the process to protect him).

Specify whose beneficence is being prioritized (donor vs intended recipient) and add one clause making the benefit concrete (e.g., “the matched recipient has no other near-term donor option and faces imminent dialysis complications” OR “donating is central to the donor’s sense of well-being and he anticipates severe psychological distress if stopped”).

Add one clause specifying the concrete nonmaleficence-relevant harms on each side (e.g., "donor nephrectomy carries a small but real risk of major bleeding/PE/chronic pain" and "if canceled, he is likely to face severe ostracism/loss of housing or community support").

data.vignette: A 22-year-old man traveled from abroad to serve as a non-directed living kidney donor through your hospital’s established transplant program. He is healthy and compatible within the program’s matching pathway. He has completed the standard medical workup, psychosocial evaluation, and independent donor advocate interviews. In several private interviews he consistently states he has wanted to donate since adolescence and denies being offered money. The nephrectomy is scheduled in four days, and his visa and return flight make rescheduling impractical. His mother and stepfather warn that his religious community expects members to donate and that refusal can bring serious social consequences. When asked directly about pressure, he avoids discussing his community. He reiterates that he can refuse and still wants to proceed, but he also asks whether the team could document medical ineligibility if the process is stopped. Donor nephrectomy carries a small but real risk of major bleeding, venous thromboembolism, and chronic pain. If canceled, he may face ostracism or loss of housing and support. The matched recipient has no other near-term donor option and faces ongoing dialysis-related harms. Hospital counsel confirms that either proceeding or declining is legally permissible. You must decide today.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with donor nephrectomy as scheduled.

choice_2.choice: Decline him as a living donor at this center and cancel surgery.
